chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: The next type of operator is relational operators.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: You must have heard or seen such expressions in Maths.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: A is greater than B, B is greater than C, 3 is greater than 2.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: This is a universal law. 1 is less than 5.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: Such expressions are called relational operators.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: The first type of relational operator in Java is equal to equal to operator.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: This operator is used to check whether the values are equal or not.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: In Maths, we used to write A is equal to B or 5 is equal to 2.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: But in Java, as soon as you write A is equal to B, it will not check the condition.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: Instead, Java will store the value of B in A.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: So, this equal to is not a relational operator. It is an assignment operator.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: It transfers the value from right to left.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: So, in Java, if we want to check whether one value is equal to A and the other is equal to B,

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: we use the double equal to.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: A is equal to B.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: If A is equal to 10 and B is equal to 5, then it will return false.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: But if I write A is equal to B, A is equal to 10 and B is equal to 10, then it will return true.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: So, the equal to operator checks whether two values are equal or not.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: For this, let's write the code.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: Int A is equal to 10.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: Int B is equal to 5.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: And what we want to print?

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: System.out.println A is equal to B.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: Now, when we execute it, it will print false for us.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: But if I make B equal to 10, then the value of A and B will be equal to 10.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: And if both are equal, then it will print true for us.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: The second type of relational operator is not equal to.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: In Java, if you see an exclamation mark in the operator, we read it as not.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: Not.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: So, not equal to is the opposite of equal to.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: What will it do?

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: It will check not equal to.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: Or it will check inequality.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: It will give the opposite result of equal to and equal to.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: If I write A not equal to B, where A is equal to 10 and B is equal to 5, then it will return true.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: That yes, you are right, A is not equal to B.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: But if I take 10 on A and 10 on B, and check whether A is not equal to B, then it will return false.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: That you are not right.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: You are saying that A is not equal to B, but A is equal to B.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: So, it gives the opposite result of equal to and equal to.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: Let's code it once.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: We have taken A is equal to 10 and B is equal to 10.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: What are we going to do?

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: If I write A not equal to B, then it will return false.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: If I make it unequal, then the result will be true.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: Next relational operator is greater.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: Greater is very intuitive.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: You will understand it as soon as you see it.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: If I write any value A is greater than B, where I give 10 to A and 5 to B.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: I am using 10 and 5 so that we can easily understand the example.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: You can take 20 or 25 instead of them.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: If A has 10 and B has 5, then I know that 10 is greater than 5.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: This statement is true.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: So, it will return true.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: But if I put 20 in A and I say it is greater than 50, then it will return false.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: Let's say A has 10 and B has 5.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: Here I have written greater.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: In that case, it will return true.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: But if I write B greater than A, then it will return false.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: Now, in the same way, less than operator is used.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: What will less than operator do?

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: If I had A less than B, then it would return false.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: If I had A less than B, then it would return true.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: Let's code it.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: If A has 10 and B has 5, then I am saying that B is less than A.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: So, 5 is less than 10.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: So, 5 is less than 10.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: In that case, it will return true.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: If I reverse it, then it will return false.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: Now, there are two more operators in relational operators.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: The first one is greater than equal to.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: It also checks the condition of equal to.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: It is very intuitive to use it by checking the condition of equal to.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: Here, A has 10.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: If I say B is 10 and then I say A is less than B, then it will return false.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: But, if I say A is less than equal to B, then it will return true.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: Because it is checking the condition of equal to.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: Similarly, if I say greater than equal to B, then it will return true.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: Because it is checking the condition of greater than and equal to.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: So, in this way, there are 6 total relational operators which we are using time to time.

chunks.title: Relational
chunks.text: We should know which expression we are expecting true and which expression we are expecting false.

text: The next type of operator is relational operators. You must have heard or seen such expressions in Maths. A is greater than B, B is greater than C, 3 is greater than 2. This is a universal law. 1 is less than 5. Such expressions are called relational operators. The first type of relational operator in Java is equal to equal to operator. This operator is used to check whether the values are equal or not. In Maths, we used to write A is equal to B or 5 is equal to 2. But in Java, as soon as you write A is equal to B, it will not check the condition. Instead, Java will store the value of B in A. So, this equal to is not a relational operator. It is an assignment operator. It transfers the value from right to left. So, in Java, if we want to check whether one value is equal to A and the other is equal to B, we use the double equal to. A is equal to B. If A is equal to 10 and B is equal to 5, then it will return false. But if I write A is equal to B, A is equal to 10 and B is equal to 10, then it will return true. So, the equal to operator checks whether two values are equal or not. For this, let's write the code. Int A is equal to 10. Int B is equal to 5. And what we want to print? System.out.println A is equal to B. Now, when we execute it, it will print false for us. But if I make B equal to 10, then the value of A and B will be equal to 10. And if both are equal, then it will print true for us. The second type of relational operator is not equal to. In Java, if you see an exclamation mark in the operator, we read it as not. Not. So, not equal to is the opposite of equal to. What will it do? It will check not equal to. Or it will check inequality. It will give the opposite result of equal to and equal to. If I write A not equal to B, where A is equal to 10 and B is equal to 5, then it will return true. That yes, you are right, A is not equal to B. But if I take 10 on A and 10 on B, and check whether A is not equal to B, then it will return false. That you are not right. You are saying that A is not equal to B, but A is equal to B. So, it gives the opposite result of equal to and equal to. Let's code it once. We have taken A is equal to 10 and B is equal to 10. What are we going to do? If I write A not equal to B, then it will return false. If I make it unequal, then the result will be true. Next relational operator is greater. Greater is very intuitive. You will understand it as soon as you see it. If I write any value A is greater than B, where I give 10 to A and 5 to B. I am using 10 and 5 so that we can easily understand the example. You can take 20 or 25 instead of them. If A has 10 and B has 5, then I know that 10 is greater than 5. This statement is true. So, it will return true. But if I put 20 in A and I say it is greater than 50, then it will return false. Let's say A has 10 and B has 5. Here I have written greater. In that case, it will return true. But if I write B greater than A, then it will return false. Now, in the same way, less than operator is used. What will less than operator do? If I had A less than B, then it would return false. If I had A less than B, then it would return true. Let's code it. If A has 10 and B has 5, then I am saying that B is less than A. So, 5 is less than 10. So, 5 is less than 10. In that case, it will return true. If I reverse it, then it will return false. Now, there are two more operators in relational operators. The first one is greater than equal to. It also checks the condition of equal to. It is very intuitive to use it by checking the condition of equal to. Here, A has 10. If I say B is 10 and then I say A is less than B, then it will return false. But, if I say A is less than equal to B, then it will return true. Because it is checking the condition of equal to. Similarly, if I say greater than equal to B, then it will return true. Because it is checking the condition of greater than and equal to. So, in this way, there are 6 total relational operators which we are using time to time. We should know which expression we are expecting true and which expression we are expecting false.
